title: Geth v1.8.20 & v1.8.21 full sync crashing (fatal error: runtime: out of memory)
body:
#### System information

Geth version: Geth v.1.8.21-stable  (also tested with v1.8.20-stable)
OS & Version: Debian 9
1 core, 8 GB of memory, no swap

#### Expected behaviour
Not crashing

#### Actual behaviour
Crashing

#### Steps to reproduce the behaviour
Clone repo, checkout tags/v1.8.21, build and start a full sync:
`$ ./go-ethereum/build/bin/geth --syncmode "full" --gcmode "full"`

#### Backtrace

I have datadir and complete output log, let me know if you want them and I'll upload them somewhere.

Below is the tail of the output log.

Hi @anduck.

First, let me make it clear that I have no association with the Ethereum Foundation. I just use their software.

This is speculation on my part, but the short answer is that the kernel is panicking due to running low on memory, and is killing Geth to keep the system from crashing. If you're running anything else, kill those processes while Geth is syncing. If you don't know what processes you can kill, then you're probably better off setting up a new machine to run Geth. If you don't want to do either of those things, try adding the cache option when you start Geth, and set it to something a bit lower, like 512, which is half of the default value:
`$ ./go-ethereum/build/bin/geth --syncmode "full" --gcmode "full" --cache 512`
The bad part of lowering the cache is it may take longer for the node to sync.

Anyway, on with the longer explanation.

I encountered a similar issue while running a full Geth node on an AWS t3.medium (2 vCPU, and 4 GiB memory) EC2, and Ubuntu Server 18.04.1 LTS. I swapped that for a t3.large (2 vCPU, and 8 GiB memory), and Geth has not (yet) crashed due an out of memory issue. However, I have noticed that the various memory metrics are teetering on the low side. I'm willing to bet that if I run some other software, the out of memory killer will step in, and kill Geth.

So is your machine a fresh install of Debian, running no other software, or are you running something on the side? Maybe a database, web server, virus scanner, or intrusion prevention software? Heck, maybe running a GUI would be enough to push it over the edge? That's just a guess though.

You can view your memory usage by running the `top` program from terminal. At the top of that program, you will see  some information about cpu, and memory usage. If you press Shift + E, you will see the "KiB Mem" field change to "MiB", then "GiB", and so on. Personally, I find it easier to read in mebibytes. Next, press Shift + M to sort processes by most memory used. This information, while helpful, does not necessarily relate to when a process may be killed by the kernel. However, the out of memory killer will tend to kill whatever process is using the highest percentage of memory, as it will try to kill the least amount of processes to remedy the low memory issue to create the least amount of system instability. Press Q to quit the top program.

Next, you can run `free -lm` (that's a lower case L to show high and low memory, and a lower case M to show the output in megabytes) from terminal. This will show you memory usage, with low memory (kernel has direct physical access), and high memory (kernel does not have direct physical access, and must be mapped via virtual address). If you are running a 32-bit system, you will see both a low, and high, memory. 64-bit systems will just show low memory. Take a look at the free column here.

By now you're probably wondering why you have such a low amount of free memory. Go ahead and run `cat /proc/meminfo` from terminal. This will show you things like memory being used by buffers, cache, what's active/inactive, and lot's of other information. The buffer is things in transit, and generally isn't very important, as things come and go so quickly. The cache is things that are being read, or written, to the disk. This will probably show a high utilization when syncing a new node, as Geth tends to be a bit hard on the database it uses, and thus the disk since the default cache option is relatively low compared to the amount of chain data, while syncing a new node, since it has to validate so many transactions.

Another fun, but not necessary here, fact is that the out of memory killer will keep a score for each process. If you run `ps aux | grep geth`, you will see the process ID just after the user name:
`ubuntu    1359 50.7 33.9 5830804 2773496 pts/1 Sl+  Jan23 1317:08 geth --syncmode full --gcmode archive --nousb --ws --wsapi web3,eth,net,debug,txpool --wsaddr 0.0.0.0 --wsorigins * --rpc --rpcaddr 0.0.0.0 --rpccorsdomain * --rpcapi web3,eth,net,debug,txpool console`
Here, my Geth process ID is 1359. Quick side note for the internet, yes, I realize I'm running an unsecured node. It's a non-issue due to reasons. Anyway, run "cat /proc/1359/oom_score" (without the quotes, and replace 1359 with your Geth process ID), and it will give you a number. The higher that number is (compared to other running processes), the greater the chance is the out of memory killer will kill that process in the event the system runs low on memory.

I don't know if this will be helpful, but I hope it is!
